newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Bangladesh's Eastern Bank 1995 profit seen surging.
newsitem.headline: Bangladesh's Eastern Bank 1995 profit seen surging.

text.p: Bangladesh's Eastern Bank Ltd (EBL) said on Monday its net profit could leap to 137 million taka ($3.2 million) in calendar 1995 against just 5.4 million taka in 1994, but it would continue to deny dividends to shareholders.
The EBL emerged after liquidation of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International (overseas) operation in Bangladesh, and began functioning in 1992 with a liability of 3.16 billion taka.
"The bank is still recovering from losses since the takeover," said managing director A.I.M. Iftikar Rahman. The bank has never offered dividends since listing on the Dhaka Stock Exchange in 1993.
EBL has paid-up capital of 600 million taka. Its 100 taka share was last traded on October 21 at 97.5 taka.
EBL officials said the private-sector bank, which will hold its annual meeting on Thursday, had an estimated net profit of 137 million taka in 1995, from 5.4 million taka in 1994.
The officials said the bank would not be able to pay a dividend to its shareholders.

"It has been felt by all concerned that it would not be prudent and fair to declare a dividend before the review of BCCI assets and liabilities in 1997," one official said. Bangladesh's central bank will handle the review.
The officials said the bank incurred an operating loss of 20 million taka in 1992 after it took over from BCCI.
"The year 1995 was a year of success and achievements for Eastern Bank Limited (EBL) despite political agitation and upheavals paralysing trade, commerce and industry," Rahman told Reuters.
Bangladesh was hit by frequent opposition-led general strikes and transport shutdowns through 1995 and early 1996, which forced then prime minister Begum Khaleda Zia to resign in March.
Operating profit increased to 193 million taka in 1995 from 53 million taka the previous year.
Rahman forecast the bank's 1996 operating profit at more than 270 million taka. Operating profit in 1994 was 53 million taka.
"The market share of the company is not very significant. We are only four years old. The upward trend of operating profit of the bank reflects our energetic endeavour," Rahman told Reuters.

The Bank handled import and export trade worth $114 million and $62 million respectively in 1995. The country's total imports in the same period were $5,834 million and exports were recorded at $3,473 million. ($1 = 42.5 taka)
